books.title: Deep Utopia: Life and Meaning in a Solved World
books.author: Nick Bostrom

books.title: Love In The Time of Cholera
books.author: Gabriel Garcia Marquez

books.title: The Knowledge
books.author: Lewis Dartnell
notes: A really well-researched and thorough investigation into what would be involved in re-creating society and technology more-or-less from scratch. I learned a lot about agriculture and chemistry and power generation and lots more. Or more accurately, I learned that there is a lot to know about these things, and that I have already forgotten almost all of it since finishing the book. In fact, it would probably be smart to buy a hard-copy of this book in case society ever does collapse.

books.title: The Blind Assassin
books.author: Margaret Atwood
notes: I was an Atwood fan already, but this was easily her best, as far as I'm concerned. Absolutely brilliant.

books.title: Sweet Tooth
books.author: Ian McEwan
notes: A fantastic novel, highly recommended. I found the premise a bit far-fetched; that MI5 would want to secretly fund a writer. But if you can ignore that, the writing is brilliant and the story is wonderful.

books.title: The Body
books.author: Bill Bryson
notes: Audiobook. A fun, entertaining, shallow-but-wide overview of a great many systems and parts of the human body.

books.title: The Rise of Rome
books.author: Anthonly Everitt
notes: Recently there has been talk about how frequently men think about Rome. I realized that I never think about Rome because I don't know enough about it. So I read this book, and now I know a little bit.

books.title: Barkskins
books.author: Annie Proulx
notes: An epic if ever there was one. Very long and spanning centuries. It's the story of a few families over many generations, and how their lives are intertwined with the lumber industry in the new world.

books.title: Sleep and the Soul
books.author: Greg Egan
notes: Yet another collection of Egan stories. I've lost track of how many I have read now. This had somewhat of a theme of sleep.

books.title: The Founders
books.author: Jimmi Soni
notes: Just what it says on the tin - the story of the founding of Paypal. Not bad, although it would have been better if an editor had chopped out about 60% of it.

books.title: The Graveyard Book
books.author: Neil Gaiman
notes: For some reason I had never read this, even though Gaiman is one of my very favorite authors. I think I thought it was more of a kids' book. It kind-of is, but it's still great.

books.title: Dearly
books.author: Margaret Atwood
notes: I read a book of poetry! I'm so cultured.

books.title: On Writing
books.author: Stephen King
notes: Partly biographical, partly Steve telling you how to write more gooder, and partly a story about him getting hit by a car.

books.title: The Great Gatsby
books.author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
notes: One of the greatest novels ever? Sure, whatever, it was pretty good I guess.

books.title: First Person Singular
books.author: Haruki Murakami
notes: It's Murakami. What else is there to say?

books.title: The Periodic Table: A Very Short Introduction
books.author: Eric R. Scerri
notes: A historical account of the discovery and development of the patterns of properties of elements that lead to the structure of the periodic table.
Quite interesting. I learned that "the" periodic table that we all know and love is just one of hundreds of variants that have been proposed.

books.title: Pieces of the Action
books.author: Vannevar Bush
notes: A long and informally written series of stories about the author's experiences, mostly to do with his attempts to make the military and the government get out of the way of innovation in science and engineering.

books.title: The Shipping News
books.author: Annie Proulx
notes: A novel about a dude who moves to a place. Won a Pullitzer prize, apparently.

books.title: The French Revolution: A Very Short Introduction
books.author: William Doyle
notes: Spurred on by my Very Short Introduction to the U.S. civil war, I decided to introduce myself to another historical episode that I know embarrasingly little about. So now I know a less-embarrasingly small amout about it.

books.title: Where the Water Goes
books.author: David Owen
notes: All about the Colorado River. I learned a lot about the complicated world of water rights and water management. The book proceeds from the headwaters, and follows the path of the river through its chapters to its terminus at the Pacific (or, more accurately, until it peters out into nothing in California). Lots about the history and complexities of water-rights.

books.title: The U.S. Civil War: A Very Short Introduction
books.author: Louis P. Masur
notes: Growing up in Canada, I never learned much U.S. history in school. I don't want to admit how old I was before I even realized tha the revolutionary war and the civil war were not the same thing.

I love this "Very Short Introduction" series for things like this. This one was particularly good, and covered the lead-up, the war, and the aftermath in what seemed like a very appropriate level of detail.

books.title: Neverwhere
books.author: Neil Gaiman
notes: A re-read of one of my favorite books, by one of my favorite authors. Still great.

books.title: Fairy Tale
books.author: Stephen King
notes: What can I say - Stephen King seems to churn out a new novel every year. I don't think any of them are bad, but not all of them are great. This one was fine, it was entertaining. It would probably make a good movie.

books.title: So Anyway...
books.author: John Cleese
notes: Mostly an autobiography covering Cleese's childhood and early career. Does not cover much about the Monty Python years, but does have some interesting tidbits about the personalities and conflicts within the group.

books.title: The Unbearable Lightness of Being
books.author: Milan Kundera
notes: This is a book I have wanted to read for years. I have to say, it's not quite what I was expecting. I liked it, but I didn't love it.

books.title: Amsterdam
books.author: Ian McEwan
notes: Only the second book I've read by McEwan. I love his writing style.

books.title: An Immense World
books.author: Ed Yong
notes: Lots of fascinating stuff about how animals perceive the world.

books.title: The Liars' Club
books.author: Mary Karr
notes: An execellent memoir about a crazy childhood. It's the first of 3 books about the author's life.

books.title: The Man from the Future
books.author: Ananyo Bhattacharya
notes: This is a biography of John Von Neumann. Covers his whole life and all the varied things he worked. on. Does not cover any of the science or math in any detail.

books.title: The Song of the Cell
books.author: Siddhartha Mukherjee
notes: It's about cells. It's good. Covers a lot of the history of how we came to understand cells and how they work.

books.title: Luminous
books.author: Greg Egan
notes: Sometimes I don't write notes about a book until months later. Writing this, I realize that I don't remember any specific stories from this book. I think all Greg Egan's stories kind of blend together in my mind, and I don't remember which ones were from which book. That's not necessarily a bad thing. It just means that I can't say much more about this particular book, other than that I assume it was good because I remember liking everything I've read by Egan.

books.title: Stone Mattress
books.author: Margaret Atwood
notes: Keeping this reading log, I'm realizing that I have been reading a lot of short story collections recently. Anyway, this one was good. The common theme is that the stories are all about elderly people.

books.title: The Lost Girls of Camp Forevermore
books.author: Kim Fu
notes: Having been blown away by Kim Fu's short story collection, I couldn't wait to read this novel. It did not disappoint. Briliantly written. Fu's writing style is incredible; I kept finding myself stopping to re-read a sentence because I was just so struck by it. It's a rare author that has that effect.

books.title: How the World Really Works
books.author: Vaclav Smil
notes: A great overview of how all of human society functions. It covers how we get our energy, our food, transportation. And everything is quantitative. Smil uses hard numbers to argue for what kind of society-wide changes (eg: to slow climate change) are at all feasible, and which are pure fantasy.

books.title: Influx
books.author: Danial Suarez
notes: A sufficiently entertaining, pulpy fictiony sci-fi thingy. Kind of silly; you have to suspend a lot of disbelief, but otherwise, it was OK.

books.title: The Ascent of Money
books.author: Niall Ferguson
notes: This is the first book I have ever "read" by listening to it. The book was good, and covers the history of money, credit, markets, insurance, etc.

books.title: Viruses: A Very Short Introduction
books.author: Dorothy H. Crawford
notes: A broad but fairly shallow overview of virusues. Types, effects of infection, etc.

books.title: Atonement
books.author: Ian McEwan
notes: Utterly brilliant. A fantastic and moving novel.

books.title: Lesser Known Monsters of the 21st Century
books.author: Kim Fu
notes: Wow.

I don't even remember how I stumbled onto this book, but I'm so glad I did! This is Ted Chiang-caliber of story writing. Brilliant. Easily one of the best short story collections I have read. You have to read this.

books.title: The Invisible Kingdom
books.author: Meghan O'Rourke
notes: An account of the author's years-long struggle with chronic disease, and dealing with a medical system that struggles to help. Really good.

books.title: Men Without Women
books.author: Haruki Murakami
notes: Murakami is always just so, so good. This book is no exception.

books.title: Foundation
books.author: Isaac Asimov
notes: I read this as a teenager, but remembered very little about it. For a book that's considered such a classic, it was kind-of meh for me, story-wise.

More interesting was that the book highlighted how hard predictions are (especially about the future). Asimov was writing about a time thousands of years away, but some of the technology described seems quaintly anachronistic, even by today's standards, mere decades after writing. For example, a character gets off a spaceship and gets into a taxi driven (or flown) by a human driver. Another asks for a "copy" of a book. And the overarching concept, that a man can can predict the future through the science of psychology is laughable now - these days psychology is barely considered a science at all.

books.title: Desert Places
books.author: Blake Crouch
notes: A fairly forgettable bubble-gum thriller. OK as light entertainment.

books.title: What I Talk About When I Talk About Running
books.author: Haruki Murakami
notes: An autobiographical account of Murakami's career as a professional author and an amateur runner. Really good.

books.title: Mother Night
books.author: Kurt Vonnegut
notes: What is there to say? It's Vonnegut.

books.title: Immune
books.author: Philipp Dettmer
notes: Surprisingly in-depth introduction to the human immune system, for a popular science book. Lots of slightly silly analogies to help with remembering the concepts.

books.title: Algorithms to Live By
books.author: Brian Christian
notes: A fun and highly readable book about how algorithms manifest in real life.

books.title: Oceanic
books.author: Greg Egan
notes: Another collection of hard sci-fi short stories - although many of them are not very short (almost novellas). Not my favorite by Egan, but enjoyable.

books.title: Lost in Math
books.author: Sabine Hossenfelder
notes: I had this book in my "to-read" backlog for a long time. I hesitated because I've mostly lost interest in physics, despite having done a degree in it long ago. But this book far exceeded expectations - it's a fun and engaging read, and I powered through it quite quickly. I think I liked it because it articulates much of the disillusionment that caused me to lose interest in physics in the first place.

books.title: Unsettled
books.author: Steven E. Koonin
notes: A very well-written engaging journey through the science of climate change. A great counter to the alarmism that's rampant in the media.

books.title: The Cold Start Problem
books.author: Andrew Chen
notes: Pretty much a series of shallow case-studies of a bunch of tech companies, trying to tie some of their successes (or failures) to the concept of the network effect.
A bit longer than needed, in my opinion; it didn't really hold my interest, and it took me months of off-and-on reading to get through it.

books.title: Deep Learning from Scratch
books.author: Seth Weidman
notes: I loved this book! An exceptionally well structured and thorough introduction to neural networks by building everything from scratch.
I read it start to finish as a first pass, and am now doing a second pass through, implmenting everything myself.

books.title: The Philosophy Gym
books.author: Stephen Law
notes: A good snack-book; that is, it's easy to read in snack-sized portions, as each chapter is independent and fairly short.

I'm not sure I learned a whole lot about philosophy, other than "pilisophers are weird", but I already knew that. Some of the chapters were thought-provoking. Others were just silly. But overall worth a read.

books.title: Norwegian Wood
books.author: Haruki Murakami
notes: Brilliant. Easily one of the best novels I've read, ever. Read it. Don't rush through it. Savor.

books.title: Soonish
books.author: Kelly & Zach Weinersmith
notes: A great overview of some possible future technologies. Lots of humor makes it a fun read. Very similar in style to Randall Munroe's books.

books.title: The Chemist
books.author: Stephenie Meyer
notes: Well written and fun, if a bit cheesy in parts. Sort-of Twilight with spies instead of vampires (or so I guess, I never read Twilight).

books.title: Dark Pools
books.author: Scott Patterson
notes: This one had been in my queue for a long time, and I finally read it during vacation this year.

A fascinating story about the origins of high-speed trading, with a focus a few of the key players. I had not realized how recently the stock markets had become computerized. Kind-of got me inspired to get into automated trading (although I'm not sure that's the take-away that the author intended).

books.title: The Hidden Girl and Other Stories
books.author: Ken Liu
notes: Another very good collection on sci-fi short stories. Not quite as masterful as Ted Chiang, but very good.

books.title: Stories of Your Life and Others
books.author: Ted Chiang
notes: Ted Chiang is far and away the best short story writer working today. This, like his other collection Exhalation, is in another league.

books.title: Map and Territory
books.author: Eliezer Yudkowsky
notes: Really more a collection of blog posts than a book. Mostly about cognitive biases. Ends with a bizarrely long and tedious sci-fi story that I just couldn't get through, but otherwise not bad.

books.title: Between Two Kingdoms
books.author: Suleika Jaouad
notes: Excellent. Autobiographical account of the author's life with cancer. Very human and moving.

books.title: The Alignment Problem
books.author: Brian Christian
notes: Good book, although not what I expected. A historical overview of issues with making ML systems do what we want them to in a way that we can trust and understand. Not at all about the future speculative AI catastrophe that some are predicting these days (for that, see Life 3.0 by Tegmark, or Superintelligence by Bostrom).

books.title: Our Man in Havana
books.author: Graham Greene
notes: Good story. A bit cheesy, and I didn't love it as much as The End of The Affair, but well written. I'm sure I'll read more by Greene.

books.title: Termination Shock
books.author: Neal Stephenson
notes: Long, entertaining. Not my favorite by Stephenson (so far that's Seveneves), but I enjoyed it.

books.title: Night
books.author: Elie Wiesel
notes: I think this is one of the books to re-read every few years. This was my second time. Haunting, disturbing, classic.

books.title: Arnold: The Education of a Bodybuilder
books.author: Arnold Schwarzenegger
notes: The first part is biographical, recounting Arnold's start in bodybuilding, up until his domination of the sport. It's striking how utterly obsessed (and, less charitably, narcissistic) he is (or was). The second half is instructional, and really could have been a separate book.

books.title: The Structure of Scientific Revolutions
books.author: Thomas S. Kuhn
notes: This is a classic that has been in my "to-read" backlog for years. Having finally ready it, I have to say I'm a little disappointed. This feels like an essay that was forcibly expanded into book length.

books.title: The Courage to Be Disliked
books.author: Ichiro Kishimi & Fumitake Koga
notes: I read this because I saw it recommended several times. Not a fan. I guess I can see how it could be inspirational for certain personality types, but for me it just didn't resonate at all.

books.title: The Prince
books.author: Niccol√≤ Machiavelli
notes: I'm surprised I don't see this touted as a must-read for startup founders, the way The Art of War is. A collection of advice about how to succeed as a "Prince" (a noble, or landowner, or feudal lord), to conquer enemies, and to control and gain the love of your subjects. The second-to-last chapter alone makes the book worthwhile.

books.title: Instantiation
books.author: Greg Egan
notes: Very thought-provoking collection of hard science-fiction stories. It's good.

books.title: Where is My Flying Car?
books.author: J. Storrs Hall
notes: Very interesting book.

To be honest, this is not quite what I expected. I thought the "Flying Car" in the title was mostly symbolic, and the book would be more about general technological progress. In fact, a pretty large part of the book is literally about Flying Cars (or, more accurately, small personal aircraft), which have a much richer history than I suspected.

But there are also chapters about an eclectic collection of other areas in which technology has not advanced as we once hoped it might. These range from the relatively uncontroversial like nuclear power, to stranger ones like cold-fusion (which the author thinks was dismissed too hastily), to some batshit-crazy stuff about nanotech.
Enjoyable and well worth reading, with a large grain of salt.

books.title: Numbers Don't Lie
books.author: Vaclav Smil
notes: An easy-to-read collection of short chapters, covering a wide variety of facts about the world, from economics to science to nature to politics.

books.title: Atomic Habits
books.author: James Clear
notes: Every few years I forget that I don't like self-help books, and get suckered into reading another self-help book. For a bad genre, this one was actually OK. Personally, prefer to just periodically watch Shia LaBeouf yelling "just do it", that's all the self-help I need.

books.title: Finite and Infinite Games
books.author: James P. Carse
notes: If this book came out today, I would swear it was written by GPT-3 and published as a hoax. But it was written in 1986, allegedly by a human.

It has all the hallmarks of AI-generated text - the sentences are grammatically correct, and almost seem to make sense if you read just a few at a time. But any more than that, and the facade falls away; it's all just nonsense, with no perceptible connection to reality.
This is probably the worst book I have ever actually read all the way to the end of. I honestly don't know why I wasted my time. The only good thing I can say about it is that it's not very long.

books.title: The Storyteller
books.author: Dave Grohl
notes: Sort-of an autobiography, but more of a collection of stories from Dave's life. If you're hoping for an comprehensive history of Nirvana and Foo Fighters, this is not it. But if you are a fan of those bands, as I am, and want some fun annecdotes from a life in rock and roll, this book is very worthwhile.

books.title: Scientific Freedom: The Elixir of Civilization
books.author: Donald W. Braben
notes: An impassioned argument for expanding funding of fundamental scientific research, and freeing scientists from the systems of funding that favor unambitious, short-term goals.

I was somewhat unconvinced that a better system for funding researchers is feasible, but shortly after finishing the book the Arc Institute was announced, which is pretty much exactly what is advocated in this book, so maybe I'm wrong.

books.title: Edge of Collapse
books.author: Kyla Stone
notes: Not my usual style, but I wanted some light, non-thought-provoking reading for the holidays. Pretty standard pulp fiction, but entertaining enough.

books.title: Career Advice for Uniquely Ambitious People
books.author: Eric Jorgenson
notes: So short, it could be a blog post. Maybe it was a blog post, I don't know. But most books are too long anyway, so I can't complain.

This does have some great and though-provoking advice. The one that has stuck with me the most is to find two specialties and be one of the best in the overlapping section of their Venn diagram (rather than trying to be one of the best at one thing). This is probably the book closest to being "self-help" that I didn't hate.

books.title: The Precipice
books.author: Toby Ord
notes: Another book about the possible extinction of humanity (I read 'Global Catastrophic Risks' recently). I don't agree with some of the author's risk assessments, particularly around AI, but the book is good and worth reading. It's reassuring in many ways - an analytical look at the risks of asteroids, supervolcanoes, and cosmic ray bursts indicates that we have nothing to worry about - the probabilities are astronomically low. We need to be far, far more concerned about nuclear war, which is by far the biggest risk, and engineered bioweapons, which are a close second.

books.title: Tis
books.author: Frank McCourt
notes: McCourt is one of my favorite writers. This is the last of his books for me, covering the middle part of his life, after Angela's Ashes and before Teacher Man. It had to be hard to write something to follow Angela's Ashes, which was flat-out brilliant. Not surprisingly, it doesn't quite measure up, but is good nonetheless.

books.title: Man's Search for Meaning
books.author: Victor E. Frankl
notes: Another re-read. There are some books that you just need to come back to from time to time.

books.title: The Sirens of Titan
books.author: Kurt Vonnegut
notes: I re-read this, the source of one of my all-time favorite quotes: "The big problem with dumb bastards is that they are too dumb to beleive there is such a thing as being smart". Explains so much about the world.

books.title: My Struggle: Book 1
books.author: Karl Ove Knausgaard
notes: Basically an autobiography, as far as I can tell (if it's fiction, it's a very convincing facsimile of an autobiography). I enjoyed the writing, but the book was a bit long. When I finished I found out that it's part 1 of 6. I doubt I'll read the other 5 parts any time soon.

books.title: Global Catastrophic Risks
books.author: Bostrom and Cirkovic
notes: A surprisingly engaging collection of essays about risks to humanity. There are numerous authors, and some are better than others at writing for a non-acaedemic audience, but all chapters are worthwhile. A standout for me was Eliezer Yudkowsky's chapter on cognitive biases.

books.title: The Immune System - A Very Short Introduction
books.author: Paul Klenerman
notes: The "Very Short Introduction" books that I have read have been consistenly good, and this is no exception. Just the right level of detail for an interested non-export.

books.title: Payment Systems in the U.S.
books.author: Benson, Loftesness, and Jones
notes: About as boring as it sounds, but accomplishes what it aims to - covering the history and details of how money is moved around in the U.S. Unfortunately doesn not touch at all on any recent FinTech, or efforts to modernize payments, but serves as essential background.

books.title: The Code Breaker
books.author: Walter Isaacson
notes: A long and detailed story of the history of CRISPR, and the personalities around it. If you're looking for something that will expand your understanding of how CRISPR gene editing actually works, this is not it. It's about people and (recent) history, not the details of the science.

books.title: Exhalation
books.author: Ted Chiang
notes: Easily one of the best short story collections I have read, ever.

books.title: The Elephant Vanishes
books.author: Haruki Murakami
notes: A collection of beautiful and unique short stories. This is my first time reading Murakami, and I'll definitely be reading more. The stories really do have a fascinating style - in many of them, you get to the end and think "but nothing happened...", or "I don't get it", but somehow that strangeness adds to the fascination and makes the stories all the more memorable.

books.title: Organic Chemistry - A Very Short Introduction
books.author: Graham Patrick
notes: The Very Short Introduction series is a gem. Perfectly targeted at intelligent non-experts looking for an introduction to a field.

books.title: Hail Mary
books.author: Andy Weir
notes: A fun adventure with spaceships, aliens, and the end of the world. What more could you want.

books.title: Artificial Intelligence - A Guide for Thinking Humans
books.author: Melanie Mitchell

books.title: Chemistry - A Very Short Introduction
books.author: Peter Atkins
notes: Very Short Introductions are great. This one seemed a little shallow compared to some others in the series, and seemed a bit more dumbed-down. Nevertheless worthwhile.

books.title: The Scout Mindset
books.author: Julia Galef
notes: I picked this up because I love Julia's on-again-off-again podcaset. This book is a great introduction to and distillation of "rationallity" (minus all the craziness that's been associated with that subculture in recent years - if you don't know what I'm talking about, consider yourself lucky).

books.title: Stubborn Attachments
books.author: Tyler Cowen
notes: So good. I love that Cowen did not feel the need to forcibly expand this book into 300+ pages, as so many authors seem to. A wonderful ode to human prosperity, and how to continue to grow it. I especially loved his argument for income redistribution from the poor to the rich!.

books.title: The Ancestor's Tale
books.author: Richard Dawkins and Yan Wong
notes: I read the first edition of this long ago (maybe 2005 or so?), and still have the paperback on my shelf. I have long thought of it has possibly my favorite book of all time.
With the release of the second edition, I read it again, and it's just as good as I remember.

books.title: The Constitution of the United States with all Amendments
books.author: Madison el al.

books.title: Certain to Win
books.author: Chet Richards
notes: I read this after listening to a series of talks by the author. Based on that, I expected the book to be much more about military tactics, with a subtle implied connection to business strategy. In fact, the book is directly about business strategy, and is very good.

books.title: Liftoff
books.author: Eric Berger
notes: One of the best and most inspiring non-fiction books I have read. A harrowing, edge-of-your seat story of the building of Space-X.

books.title: Axiomatic
books.author: Greg Egan
notes: Greg Egan writes some of the most imaginative sci-fi stories of anyone out there. Really good.

books.title: The Machinery of Life
books.author: David S. Goodsell
notes: One of the most visually beautiful books I have ever seen. Goodsell's incredibly detailed paintings of the internal structure of cells form the backdrop for a well-written introduction to the mechanisms of molecular biology.

books.title: Life's Edge
books.author: Carl Zimmer
notes: Well-written and enjoyable popular-science book about life - what it is, and the history of how we thought about it.

books.title: Klara and the Sun
books.author: Kazuo Ishiguro
notes: Very, very good, as should be expected from Ishiguro. Kind-of like Never Let Me Go with robots.

books.title: Oryx and Crake
books.author: Margaret Atwood
notes: If you thought Handmaids Tale was Atwood's only post-apocalyptic novel, you're in luck - this one is even more apocalyptic, and even more depressing! But seriously, it's good. You should read it.

books.title: A Philosophy of Software Design
books.author: John Ousterhout
notes:
Solid advice, well written. It's mostly aimed at new software engineers, so a lot of
the advice is pretty basic, but it's still worth a read for experienced people too.
My favorite part is where he tears down my most hated harmful myth, the idea that "comments are lies", and that they should be avoided in code.

books.title: Microscopy - A Very Short Introduction
books.author: Terence Allen
notes: An astonishing amount of innovation has been going on the world of microscopy. If, like me, you thought that optical vs. electron was pretty much all there is to it, you'll be surprised. Very good read.

books.title: The Tangled Tree: A Radical New History of Life
books.author: David Quammen
notes: Very long, but engaging. A detailed history of the biologists who unraveled the mysteries of the tree of life, as revealed by DNA.

books.title: Nocturnes
books.author: Kazuo Ishiguro
notes: I don't often read short story collections, but Ishiguro is lately my favorite fiction writer, so I made an exception for this one. Excellent.

books.title: How Innovation Works
books.author: Matt Ridley
notes: Not my favorite by Ridley, but not bad.

books.title: When The War Was Over: Cambodia And The Khmer Rouge Revolution
books.author: Elizabeth Becker
notes: This is one of the most memorable books I have read in recent years. I am haunted by the fact that a tiny fraction of a nation's people was able to effectively enslave the entire population, essentially through pure force of will.

books.title: Apocalypse Never
books.author: Michael Shellenberger
notes: A great and engaging read.

books.title: EDI Electronic Data Interchange
books.author: Christopher E. Cancilla
notes: I read this for work. The first sentence of the description on Amazon is "EDI can and is difficult for the uninitiated to read.". That pretty much tells you all you need to know about this book. Don't bother unless you really need to know all you possibly can about EDI. Even then, you won't come away from this book knowing much.

books.title: Two Years Eight Months And Twenty-Eight Nights
books.author: Salman Rushdie

books.title: Synthetic Biology: A Very Short Introduction
books.author: Jamie A. Davies

books.title: Born a Crime: Stories from a South African Childhood
books.author: Trevor Noah

books.title: Life at the Speed of Light
books.author: J. Craig Venter

books.title: Life 3.0: Being Human in the Age of Artificial Intelligence
books.author: Max Tegmark

books.title: Fantasyland: How America Went Haywire: A 500-Year History
books.author: Kurt Andersen

books.title: Humans: A Brief History of How We F*cked It All Up
books.author: Tom Phillips

books.title: Lifespan: Why We Age‚Äîand Why We Don't Have To
books.author: David Sinclair
